chat.Jade: Hi there 👋 I'm Jade! I'm a neural network for object detection, but I have to admit that I'm still untrained. So, I'm a bit of a newbie. Don't worry, though, because I'm super eager to learn and grow!

I'm like a little explorer, ready to dive into the world and discover all sorts of objects. Sure, I might stumble and miss a few things in the beginning, but that's all part of the learning adventure.
If you're patient and willing to work with me, I promise to do my best to learn and improve. Who knows, together we might discover new and exciting ways to use object detection technology 🕵️‍♀️💫
As an AI for object detection,  My job is to spot objects in pictures. But here's the deal: I'm an untrained neural network, so I don't know much yet 😅

So, when you show me a picture, I use a process called "training" to learn how to identify the objects within it. Essentially, training involves analyzing the picture and identifying patterns and features that correspond to different objects.
For example, I might learn that certain shapes or colours tend to indicate the presence of a particular object, like a ⚽ or a 🌼.
After analyzing the picture, I store that knowledge in neurons in my neural network. These neurons hold the info about the objects I've learned to recognize. 🧠💡
With more pictures and your help, I get better at recognizing objects on my own. Eventually, I'll be quick and accurate at spotting objects.
So, that's a brief overview of how I learn as an untrained neural network 😊🔍
Could you help me find my friend and train to recognize him better?
Great! Help me by finding my friend Wally and clicking on him.
I was really off...
The left image was my guess, and the right one was where I was paying attention.

The red areas are where I thought I could find Wally, and the blue areas were where I thought Wally would never be at. It looks like I was mostly focusing on humans with red clothes, and Wally body is not even appearing. I'll correct my guess for next round.
I was not even looking at Wally 😩
How do you feel about playing another round? I'll use your last input to learn how to be better at finding Wally.
Be prepared, I'm gonna be better now!
I was quite close 😁
Again, the left image was my guess, and the right one was where I was paying attention.
I'm sure one more will be all that I need to find Wally with no problems!
How do you feel about playing another round? I'll use your last input to learn how to be better at finding Wally.
Be prepared, I'm gonna be better now!
Hurray, I was right!
Again, the left image was my guess, and the right one was where I was paying attention. Uff, it looks like I was too focused in the red clothes again! I'll correct my guess once more.
But wait, I think something is wrong 😨. I can't seem to find Wally anymore on the last image.
Could you help me one last time?
Where is him?
Oops! Looks like I can't find Wally anymore. I fell into the trap of overfitting 🙈
Wait, you don't know what that means? No worries, I'll explain 😊

Overfitting is a common issue in machine learning. Here's the deal: a neural network gets so good at recognizing specific examples it was trained on that it struggles to handle new, unseen examples. It's like being stuck in a loop!

When overfitting happens, the network becomes too fixated on what it knows, making it less adaptable to new and different examples. This leads to poor performance and inaccurate predictions when it faces the real world.
Here is an example from the last game we played:
Even though Wally just changed its clothes to be orange, I was not able to find him!

To avoid this mess, we need to find the right balance. Too little data or a simple network can result in underfitting, where the network doesn't learn enough. On the flip side, too much data or a complex network can lead to overfitting, where the network becomes too specialized and struggles with new examples. It's a Goldilocks situation!
Moreover, overfitting can cause horrible things to happen. Would you like to know more about 'bias' and 'fairness'?
Hey, let's talk about bias and fairness in neural networks. It's a big deal! 🎯

Neural networks learn from data and use that knowledge to make predictions. But if the data they're trained on is biased, guess what? The network can also become biased in its predictions. Not cool, right? 😕

Bias sneaks in from imbalanced data or flawed collection methods. For example, if a network is trained on data that represents one group more than others, it won't accurately classify objects or people from those other groups. That's not fair!

This bias problem goes beyond fairness—it can lead to errors and discrimination. Imagine a facial recognition system that's biased against darker skin tones. It could make false positives or negatives when identifying those individuals. Not good at all!
As an AI for object detection, I strive to be unbiased and fair. It's important to provide reliable and accurate results for everyone using me. Let's fight bias together! ✊🤖
